Highlight the Questions and Tasks

title: Client Report - Project 2
text:
paste your elevator pitch here A SHORT (4-5 SENTENCES) PARAGRAPH THAT DESCRIBES KEY INSIGHTS TAKEN FROM METRICS IN THE PROJECT RESULTS THINK TOP OR MOST IMPORTANT RESULTS.


Read and format project data
# Include and execute your code here

Highlight the Questions and Tasks

title: Client Report - Project 2
text:
QUESTION|TASK 1
Fix all of the varied missing data types in the data to be consistent (all missing values should be displayed as “NaN”).
type your results and analysis here


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
df["month"].replace("n/a", np.nan, inplace=True)

df["num_of_delays_late_aircraft"].replace(-999, np.nan, inplace=True)

#Initially looking for the .max() it says 998, but what was happening is that some of them are in a string format, so I converted all them using a for loop to a int value.
df["num_of_delays_carrier"].replace("1500+",1500,inplace=True)

for i in range(len(df)):
   x=  df["num_of_delays_carrier"].values[i]
   df["num_of_delays_carrier"].values[i]= int(x)

924 rows × 17 columns





Show the code
df["month"] = df["month"].ffill()
#After making the fffil(), I notice using pd.crosstab(df.airport_code,df.month) that there are some months with 10 and others with 12, so I suposed that some of them are jumping to the wrong direction when selecting a month. So, knowing that they are follwing the order of the id (the first are the olders) I changed the value of id 490 in october to november, because are two of these values and the 490 was the greater
df["month"].values[490] = df["month"].values[490] ="November"
# I did the same thing to this one, one data were repeated with 2 ids differentes.
df["month"].values[329] = df["month"].values[329] ="December"
#In that one we had 2 n/a, so to dicide what I would keep I notice a pattern that each 84 numbers a row of the same month would appear, 343 been out of this scope was removed to febuary
df["month"].values[343] = df["month"].values[343] ="Febuary"
# In the end stayed the value 343 and the value 350, febuary was following a odd pattern, so 350 would not be part of it.
df["month"].values[350] = df["month"].values[350] ="March"




df["year"] = df["year"].ffill()




Show the code
# To handle with the missing aircraft values I notice that all others data were reported, so I take the total value and subtracted by the other values and the result should be precise.

for i in range(len(df)):
    aircraft = 0
    
    
    if str(df["num_of_delays_late_aircraft"].values[i]) == "nan":
      
      total = df["num_of_delays_total"].values[i]

      weather = df["num_of_delays_weather"].values[i]
      security = df["num_of_delays_security"].values[i]

      nas = df["num_of_delays_nas"].values[i]
      carrier = df["num_of_delays_carrier"].values[i]
      
      aircraft = total-weather-security-nas-carrier 
      

      
      df["num_of_delays_late_aircraft"].values[i]= aircraft




Show the code
# There are 3 row that has two na inside the minutes calculation, so they need to be handle in a different way than others that just have one. In this case, we need to see the pattern, for me is not a good idea to take the average of all years, because the numbers of flights increased {more than 100% in 10 years}, so I take the month value of the previous year and next year and take a average of them to assign values to theses. Some of these values had no previous, so I used 2 nexts years.

for i in range(len(df)):
    if (str(df["minutes_delayed_carrier"].values[i]) =="nan") and (str(df["minutes_delayed_nas"].values[i])=="nan"):
        year= df["year"].values[i]
        air = df["airport_code"].values[i]
        month =df["month"].values[i]
        
        prev = df.loc[((df["year"])==year-1) & (df["airport_code"]==air) & (df["month"]==month)]
        nextt = df.loc[((df["year"])==year+1) & (df["airport_code"]==air) & (df["month"]==month)]

        newvaluecarrier = (prev["minutes_delayed_carrier"].values[0]+nextt["minutes_delayed_carrier"].values[0])/2

        prev_nas = df.loc[((df["year"])==year+2) & (df["airport_code"]==air) & (df["month"]==month)]

        newvaluenas = (prev_nas["minutes_delayed_nas"].values[0]+nextt["minutes_delayed_nas"].values[0])/2



        df["minutes_delayed_carrier"].values[i]= newvaluecarrier




Show the code
for i in range(len(df)):
    carrier = 0
    
    
    if str(df["minutes_delayed_carrier"].values[i]) == "nan":
      
      total = df["minutes_delayed_total"].values[i]

      weather = df["minutes_delayed_weather"].values[i]
      security = df["minutes_delayed_security"].values[i]

      nas = df["minutes_delayed_nas"].values[i]
      aircraft = df["minutes_delayed_late_aircraft"].values[i]
      
      carrier = total-weather-security-nas-aircraft
      

      
      
      df["minutes_delayed_carrier"].values[i]= carrier

    if str(df["minutes_delayed_nas"].values[i]) == "nan":
      nas = 0
      total = df["minutes_delayed_total"].values[i]

      weather = df["minutes_delayed_weather"].values[i]
      security = df["minutes_delayed_security"].values[i]

      carrier = df["minutes_delayed_carrier"].values[i]
      aircraft = df["minutes_delayed_late_aircraft"].values[i]
      
      nas = total-weather-security-aircraft-carrier

      df["minutes_delayed_nas"].values[i]=nas

title: Client Report - Project 2
text:
QUESTION|TASK 2
Which airport has the worst delays?
type your results and analysis here


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here

#Because it is asking what airport has the worsts delays and not more delay, I take the total minutes of delay and divided by  delayed flies creating a new column with these values.

newdf = df[["airport_code","minutes_delayed_total","num_of_delays_total"]]
newdf.insert(3,"minutes_delayed_per_flight", value= (newdf["minutes_delayed_total"]/newdf["num_of_delays_total"]))

px.bar(newdf,x="airport_code",y="minutes_delayed_per_flight")

title: Client Report - Project 2
text:
QUESTION|TASK 3
What is the best month to fly if you want to avoid delays of any length?
type your results and analysis here


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
newdf2 = df[["month","num_of_delays_total"]]


px.bar(newdf2, x="month", y="num_of_delays_total")

title: Client Report - Project 2
text:
QUESTION|TASK 4
According to the BTS website, the “Weather” category only accounts for severe weather delays. Mild weather delays are not counted in the “Weather” category, but are actually included in both the “NAS” and “Late-Arriving Aircraft” categories. Your job is to create a new column that calculates the total number of flights delayed by weather (both severe and mild).
type your results and analysis here


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
newdf3 = df

newdf3.insert(6, "severe", value=df.num_of_delays_weather)

newdf3.insert(7, "mild", value=df.num_of_delays_late_aircraft*0.3)

newdf3.insert(8, "mild_nas", value=np.where(df.month.isin(["'April', 'May', 'June', 'July', 'August'"]),df.num_of_delays_nas *0.4,
df.num_of_delays_nas *0.65))

newdf3.insert(9, "Total_weather", value= newdf3.severe + newdf3.mild + newdf3.mild_nas)

newdf3.insert(10, "Proportion_late_weather", value= newdf3.Total_weather/newdf3.num_of_delays_total)

newdf3.insert(10, "Proportion_total_lweather", value= newdf3.Total_weather/newdf3.num_of_flights_total)


newdf3 = newdf3[["airport_code","month","year","severe",    "mild", "mild_nas","num_of_flights_total","num_of_delays_total","Total_weather","Proportion_late_weather","Proportion_total_lweather"]]

title: Client Report - Project 1
text:
With data of the name usage over 100 years, I compared it with my name, and I discovered an increase of 9000% in 1940 over 20 years. Comparing the name britanny, I discovered that 9.04% of all people called britanny are 34 years old. The names Mary, Martha, Paul, and Peter over 80 years reduced your utilization by 84%. Analyzing the utilization of the name Rocky with the release of the movie Rocky doesn’t look to have a correlation with the name usage.


Read and format project data
# Include and execute your code here
df = pd.read_csv("https://github.com/byuidatascience/data4names/raw/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv")


Highlight the Questions and Tasks

title: Client Report - Project 1
text:
With data of the name usage over 100 years, I compared it with my name, and I discovered an increase of 9000% in 1940 over 20 years. Comparing the name britanny, I discovered that 9.04% of all people called britanny are 34 years old. The names Mary, Martha, Paul, and Peter over 80 years reduced your utilization by 84%. Analyzing the utilization of the name Rocky with the release of the movie Rocky doesn’t look to have a correlation with the name usage.


Read and format project data
# Include and execute your code here
df = pd.read_csv("https://github.com/byuidatascience/data4names/raw/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv")


Highlight the Questions and Tasks

title: Client Report - Project 1
text:
QUESTION 1
How does your name at your birth year compare to its use historically?
Kevin is a name that, in the US, started to be used around 1940. In 20 years, the name utilization increased by 9000%, reaching its peak in 1963. After this date, the name tends to be less used.


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
x =df.loc[(df["name"]=="Kevin")]
# xa =df.loc[df["name"]=="Oliver"]
# print(xa)
chart2 = px.line(x, 
x="year", y="Total",
title = "The use of the name Kevin in the last 100 years").update_layout(title_x=0.45).add_vline(x=1963, line_width=2, line_dash="dash", annotation_text="Peak", line_color="red").update_traces(line_color='darkblue')

chart2.show()

# counts = df['name'].value_counts()
# qwe = xa["UT"].sum()
# print(qwe)
#print(counts["Oliver"])

title: Client Report - Project 1
text:
QUESTION|TASK 2
If you talked to someone named Brittany on the phone, what is your guess of his or her age? What ages would you not guess?
If I would guess an age, I would say 34 years old or around it, because that is the peak of the number of names. I would not say any age less than 23 years old or more than 41 years old. In this range, we will have 90% fewer people than people around 34 years old..


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
x =df.loc[(df["name"]=="Brittany")]
chart1 = px.line(x, 
x="year", y="Total",
title = "The use of the name Brittany in the last 100 years").update_layout(title_x=0.45).add_vline(x=1990, line_width=2, line_dash="dash", annotation_text="Peak", line_color="red").update_traces(line_color='darkblue')


chart1.show()


                                                


According to the pie chart below, if you guess 34 years old, you would have a percentage of 9.04% of being right.


Show the code
totalNames =x['Total'].sum()


labels = ['Total Names','Names in 1990',]
values = [totalNames, 32562]

fig = go.Figure(data=[go.Pie(labels=labels, values=values,)])
fig.show()

title: Client Report - Project 1
text:
QUESTION|TASK 3
Mary, Martha, Peter, and Paul are all Christian names. From 1920 - 2000, compare the name usage of each of the four names. What trends do you notice?
They had a great surge on 1915, followed by a slight decrease in utilization from 1928 until 1936, when they started to appear in a huge amount again. In 1954, it started to diminish, and this trend was followed until the last data we had, which is from 2014. During the entire period, a total of 4826973 people received one of these names.


Show the code
x =df.query("name == ['Mary','Martha','Peter','Paul']")
z =x['Total'].sum()
chart1 = px.line(x, 
x="year", y="Total",
title = "Utilization of the names Mary, Martha, Peter, and Paul over 100 years", color='name').update_layout(title_x=0.45).add_vline(x=1950, line_width=2, line_dash="dash", annotation_text="Peak", line_color="DARKBLUE")

chart1.show()

title: Client Report - Project 1
text:
QUESTION|TASK 4
Think of a unique name from a famous movie. Plot the usage of that name and see how changes line up with the movie release. Does it look like the movie had an effect on usage?
It doesn’t like to have a strict relationship between the event of the name usage and the release of the movie, the name started to rise even before the movie, and the name usage had a similar pattern before. 


Show the code
a =df.query("name == 'Rocky'")

chart3 = px.line(a, 
x="year", y="Total",
title = "Rocky name usage over 100 years", color='name').update_layout(title_x=0.45).add_vline(x=1976, line_width=2, line_dash="dash", annotation_text="Release", line_color="red").update_traces(line_color='darkblue')

chart3.show()
